stream_context.summary: Kaze (while sick) used Photoshop to rough-out the island-shaped overworld, breaking it into 14 small load zones and mapping where each main course, cap secret and side level might sit.  Most of the session is pure design/brainstorming for the overworld’s first three zones and their gating puzzles.

development_findings.summary: The overworld will represent the whole of Yoshi’s Island, about four times the size of SM64, but split into ~14 separate loaded areas to keep performance and allow varied vibes.
development_findings.quote: I’m thinking the overworld will be around four times the size of Super Mario 64.

development_findings.summary: Design rule: if the player can see a location they must eventually be able to reach it, so cliffs and rivers are used as temporary limits, not permanent walls.
development_findings.quote: For the overworld it’s very important to me that if you can see it as a player then you can go there.

development_findings.summary: Pipes with removable corks will act as fast-travel points unlocked from the far side, reducing back-tracking once new zones open.
Part 1 layout: a beach-side cliff hub holding Course 1 (Bunny Brushwoods), a river to Dino Dino Domain, and a dune-stranded boat that slides to the water as stars are collected to reveal Course 2.
Course 2 (Rainbow Grotto/Temple) will be integrated with the main river; the temple’s back wall will be opened so water flows through a cave that doubles as the level entrance.
development_findings.quote: What if we just make the back so that the water goes that way and then into a cave … and the entrance to Course 2 could be like a water cave.

development_findings.summary: Part 2 is a jungle hiking path across the island, star-locked (≈4 stars) via a visible Bowser/Kamek magic seal to motivate early star collection.
Part 3 (west beach) hosts three courses—Ghost Ship, Zoo, Ice Cap—and is reached after the jungle; a pipe then links Part 1 and Part 3 for quick return.
Ghost Ship entrance puzzle finalised: the ship is a foggy silhouette until the player activates a lighthouse switch; a cut-scene turns the beam on the ship, clears the fog and makes the level solid.
development_findings.quote: What if the ship is here, but it’s like a shadowy fix, and you have to go into the lighthouse … and that makes the ship visible and breaks through the fog.

development_findings.summary: Zoo gating is unresolved; ideas include Wario charging admission, luring a Chain Chomp or breaking a wooden gate—final mechanic still undecided.
Side-levels will be short, gimmick-centric experiences (e.g. Esa’s sliding stage, a cannon-golf course); Kaze keeps a running list for optional additions.

context_findings.summary: Kaze streamed while very sick yet remained upbeat, repeatedly describing new ideas as “bangers”.
He and Zeina realised on-stream it was their third wedding anniversary; both had forgotten and joked about postponing celebrations.
context_findings.quote: Maybe we’ll do something fun for our anniversary… Well, you’re also sick, so maybe we’ll leave it to another day.

context_findings.summary: Current day job: Kaze is programming for Gears for Breakfast beside the ROM-hack work.
context_findings.quote: I program for Gears for Breakfast right now.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is wary of asking outsiders for favors because he feels obligated to accept sub-par work; maintains strict quality control.
context_findings.quote: If I ask someone for a favor, I can’t just say ‘actually, your help sucks’—that always feels super bad.

context_findings.summary: Design philosophy emphasises ‘anticipation/edging’: revealing tantalising locked areas that become quickly accessible once solved, to keep momentum.
context_findings.quote: Some parts of this world are going to be edging… you unlock a new area, I’m excited to see what’s going on.

biobak.summary: Agreed the overworld being ~4× SM64’s size is reasonable and engaged in technical chat (e.g., piranha AI tuning).

badub.summary: Kaze is considering asking Badub to compose the full OST and possibly do SM64 remix medleys for Bowser Mines.
badub.quote: I think Badub wants to make the whole OST.

zeina.summary: Zeina is producing concept art: sketches of Mario’s route through levels and Yoshi huts styled after Rainbow Road.
zeina.quote: Zeina’s drawing them right now to kind of look like a Rainbow Road from Mario Kart.

key_stories.title: Lighthouse unlocks the Ghost Ship
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed a memorable entrance for the Ghost Ship.  After rejecting fog-that-clears-over-time, he conceived a lighthouse puzzle: switch inside the lighthouse rotates its beam, dispelling fog and solidifying the ship.
key_stories.challenge: Make the Ghost Ship entrance unique and not just star-gated.
key_stories.process: Brainstormed anchors, tap-taps, fog mechanics; then proposed using a lighthouse cut-scene.
key_stories.outcome: Team accepted; idea logged for implementation.
key_stories.key_quote: What if the ship is here… you point the light at the ship, and that makes the ship visible and breaks through the fog.

key_stories.title: Debating star-gating mechanics
key_stories.summary: The team needs clear, in-world explanations for why courses stay locked.  Kaze weighed magic barriers, miners too weak without stars, and visible Bowser/Kamek seals to communicate star counts.
key_stories.challenge: Provide player motivation and clarity for star requirements without jarring doors.
key_stories.process: Compared Mario 64 doors, Galaxy fuel, Odyssey moons, Spyro dragons; discussed mice miners and Kamek barriers.
key_stories.outcome: Leaning toward visible magical seals plus NPC dialogue that states the needed stars.
key_stories.key_quote: Half the advantage of having a barrier that says you need 10 stars is that when you’re at eight you know ‘I just need two more’.

key_stories.title: Integrating Course 2 with the island river
key_stories.summary: Course 2’s temple originally had a blank rear wall.  Kaze decided to open it, extend the river through a cave, and reuse the same piranhas in both overworld and level to bind the geography.
key_stories.challenge: Find a logical, immersive entrance for Course 2.
key_stories.process: Discussed adding a backside cave, strong current, star-powered boat hindrance.
key_stories.outcome: Temple back wall will be removed; river and cave will serve as entrance, possibly requiring a power-up or boat puzzle after stars.
key_stories.key_quote: We could add these same piranhas in this level to the overworld—how cool would that be?

open_questions.topic: Exact star-gating system and visual language
open_questions.context: Kaze floated mice miners, Kamek seals, magic barriers but did not choose a definitive, consistent mechanic.
questions: Which gating method is finally being adopted?
How will the required star count be communicated on each gate?
Will the same mechanic be used island-wide or vary by zone?

open_questions.context: Multiple ideas—Wario toll, chain-chomp lure, breakable wooden gate—were discussed without resolution.
questions: What final mechanic will unlock the Zoo?
Does Wario remain as a character gatekeeper?
How does the puzzle tie into Yoshi’s Island lore?

open_questions.context: Boat that slides toward river as stars are earned was mentioned, but later the river-cave temple idea took precedence.
questions: Is the sliding boat still planned or replaced by the river cave?
If kept, how many stars move the boat and how is progress shown?

open_questions.context: Location above Koopa Wave Cove via cannon is decided, but no unlocking method or star gate was set.
questions: How does the player unlock the cannon?
Is the Cloud Cap a standalone cap stage or tied to a main course?

open_questions.topic: Role of side levels and Esa’s slide
open_questions.context: Kaze wants many gimmick side levels and earmarked area near Part 4 for Esa’s slide.
questions: How many side levels are targeted overall?
Will they award stars or other collectibles?
What criteria decide a side-level’s inclusion?
